awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Diverse and Resilient Beyond Paths
awd_abstract_narration:
With advances in Internet applications and their insatiable demands for bandwidth, today's networks have grown rapidly both in scale and complexity. The growing scale and complexity also drastically increase the probability of failures. This is particularly the case in today's huge data centers. It is thus imperative that networks be designed with high capacity and with built-in resiliency. Routing is central to networking, as it determines whether and where packets are to be forwarded. It is therefore essential in ensuring network resiliency. Conventional routing protocols in IP/MPLS (Internet Protocol/Multiple Protocol Label Switching) networks that underpin much of today's networking infrastructure are primarily path-based and reactive. Various IP/MPLS (proactive) fast rerouting mechanisms have also been proposed; but most of them can only handle a single link failure. The combinatorial nature of multiple link failures renders most existing path-based fast rerouting approaches ineffectual; and their complexity grows rapidly, as the number of link/node failures increases. In order to achieve high network capacity, availability and reliability, new paradigm-shifting approaches are needed for the development of future diverse and resilient routing systems.
   
Going beyond paths, this project advocates a novel routing paradigm -- dubbed routing via preorders  --  which circumvents the limitations of conventional path-based routing schemes to effectively take advantage of topological diversity inherent in a network with rich topology for diverse and resilient routing, while at the same time meeting the quality-of-service requirements (e.g., bandwidth and latency) of applications or flows. Unlike conventional path-based routing, under the proposed routing via preorders paradigm no paths are explicitly specified for routing or forwarding; instead any sequence of connected nodes contained in the routing preorder can be used, thereby circumventing the rigidity and fragility limitations of paths while also avoiding the "combinatorial curse" challenge posed by path enumeration. Hence by design, routing via preorders has built-in resiliency and load-balancing capabilities.  
 
Broader Impact: If successful, the paradigm-shifting new routing framework advanced in this research project will provide the high diversity and resiliency demanded by the Internet services and critical physical infrastructures. All of these will bring significant benefits to users, service providers and society at large. The PI will actively involve undergraduate students -- especially female students and underrepresented minorities in the research project, e.g., via NSF REU grants as well as senior design courses and  the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program (UROP)  at the PI's institution.  The PI will release the implementation of routing via preorders using the software-defined networking (SDN) platform in public domains for wide distribution and adoption, and engage in other outreach activities.

por.por_cntn:
With advances in Internet applications and their insatiable demands for bandwidth, today's networks have grown rapidly both its scale and its complexity. The growing scale and complexity also drastically increase the probability of failures. This is particularly the case in today's huge data centers. The importance of network resiliency will further grow with the emergence of 5G networks, and the rise of Internet-of-Thing (IoT) applications and cyber-physical systems. It is thus imperative that networks be designed with high capacity and with built-in resiliency.

Routing is central to networking, as it determines whether and where packets are to be forwarded. It is therefore essential in ensuring network resiliency. Conventional routing protocols in IP/MPLS networks that underpin much of today's networking infrastructure are primarily path-based and reactive. Various IP/MPLS (proactive) fast rerouting mechanisms have also been proposed; but most of them can only handle a single link failure. The combinatorial nature of multiple link failures renders most existing path-based fast rerouting approaches ineffectual; and their complexity grows rapidly, as the number of link/node failures increases. The fundamental limitation lies in the rigidity and fragility of use of paths as the basis for defining routing behaviors: a path becomes invalid whenever a node or link on it fails, thus it is very brittle. In order to achieve high network capacity, availability and reliability, new paradigm-shifting approaches are needed for the development of future diverse and resilient routing systems.

Going beyond paths, this project puts forth a novel routing paradigm ? dubbed routing via preorders ? which circumvents the limitations of conventional path-based routing schemes to effectively take advantage of topological diversity inherent in a network with rich topology for diverse and resilient routing, while at the same time meeting the quality-of-service requirements (e.g., bandwidth and latency) of applications or flows. Unlike conventional path-based routing, under the proposed routing via preorders paradigm no paths are explicitly specified for routing or forwarding; instead any sequence of connected nodes contained in the routing preorder can be used, thereby circumventing the rigidity and fragility limitations of paths while also avoiding the ?combinatorial curse? challenge posed by path enumeration Hence by design, routing via preorders has built-in resiliency and load-balancing capabilities.

Based on this novel routing paradigm, the PI and his students have developed the first provably correct, proactive routing algorithm that is resilient against arbitrary link/node failures. Namely, as long as the network failures do not disconnect a source node 𝑠 from a destination node 𝑑, our algorithm is guaranteed to route a packet from 𝑠 around failures to 𝑑 without forwarding loops; this is achieved without resorting to ?route recomputations? upon detecting network failures (as in the conventional routing algorithms and some new variants). They have also developed an innovative resilient diversity routing algorithm that ensures bounded latency for packet delivery under failures by leveraging a preorder routing structure with precomputed routing rules. Other outcomes include i) a comprehensive traffic engineering framework for software-defined wide-area networks (SD-WAN) to fairly allocate resources among various traffic classes/flows that accounts for bandwidth, delay and availability requirements;  ii) a novel scalable SD-WAN solution which not only can seamlessly aggregate multiple (heterogeneous) WAN paths into a ?big pipe?, but is also capable of adapting to network failures or congestion to provide fast failure recovery to applications; and iii) a  software-based multipath RDMA transport framework for accelerating machine learning applications in data center networks.

With the society?s growing dependence on cloud services and with the emergence of 5G network, ?Internet-of- Things? and various cyber-physical systems ? thus inter-dependence among critical infrastructures ? network resiliency becomes increasingly crticial to the society. These complex systems comprise vastly diverse arrays of hardware and software components; managing them involve enormous complexity. A routine software maintenance, a power failure due to bad weather ? or worse, a malicious cyber or physical attack ? can bring about massive failures, as attested by recent news about Amazon or  Facebook/Meta outages, among others. The solutions developed in this project will help enhance the availability and resiliency of networked systems which underpin today?s and future Internet applications and services will bring significant benefits to the society. Throughout this project, the PI and students have collaborated with various industrial partners, including AT&T, Facebook/Meta, Google, HP Enterprise. These collaborative research efforts have led to technology transfer, including several joint patents with AT&T that have been granted in 2020 and 2021. This research project has also provided both undergraduate and graduate students with hands-on experiences in network designs and system development. In particular, we have engaged several undergraduate students in this research project. We have incorporated the research outcomes in our classroom teaching and course projects as an example of new routing approaches to encourage students to think ?out-of-the box,? and as course projects for students to gain valuable ?hands-on? protocol design experiences.
